6 depressing movies about you lusting and tearing your soul a little
Tighten stomach and get tissue paper.
01 Nov 2019, 17:03 by Coralia Heppada

"Cinema is a disease. Once it gets into your bloodstream it quickly becomes the key hormone, replaces enzymes, controls pimples, plays with your soul. As with heroin, the only antidote to cinema is cinema! "


-Frank Capra

Because cinema, just like life, is not only life-giving scenes that make your soul open and your stomach dropping butterflies, but they also have their inevitable blackness, it is good to remember that "entertainment" can work and as a double-edged knife.
And because somewhere deep inside us, we are all hiding a self-balancing self and become one with the floor, here's my tried-and-tested recipe:



Depression in all its grandeur, very tearful, a strong dose of misery, futility, a strong sense that everything goes wrong, but it doesn't matter, because the sadness that is conveyed on screen and becomes art is a way to hope.
1. Biutiful - 2010



Even today, I have no idea how, why and by what logic, Biutiful made a cupcake in my New Year's Eve 2018 just before fireworks and the established brewery. I have long wanted to see this film, firstly because Javier Bardem (ðŸ˜Ž) starred and secondly because, okay, I'll be honest. I was told that this movie is going to blacken my soul from the first to the last scene and that there is no reason to watch it blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah blah Don't watch this movie, "especially when you know that this man is NOT about to see a not-so-happy movie. Anyway, not to say too much, well, as a reactionary kid and I in my old age, what can I do?
Apparently I saw it and I didn't regret it at all, it's the most beautiful depressing movie I've ever seen. The point is how I ended up seeing it New Year's Eve, anyway, it doesn't matter.

So what do we have at Biutiful?

Uxbal is a man living in deprivation, a divorced father of two young children, who must somehow nourish himself while learning that he has only a few months to live. Surrounded by the underworld of Barcelona, Uxbal, played by Javier Bardem with unparalleled perfection, carries his own cross, searching for the best foster parent to leave his children after his end is prescribed and he knows the serious health problem he is facing is beginning to devour him more and more physically and morally.




Javier Bardem as "Oxball" in Biutiful

Although biologically alive, death is present in his life and he communicates with ghosts, listening metaphysically to the sound of the end on a painful journey that exudes melancholy, futility, anxiety. To convey this agony and the daily martyrdom of the protagonist of life, Bardem resorted to the supreme dramaturgical interpretation of his career, giving the character that underlies the most essential element of all, making the soul of the spectator a thousand The brutal and ultimately human instinct of a dying man who, despite having no support from anyone anywhere, manages and finds his inner strength where everything seems to end.
And you, you just stand and watch, with your soul turned into a jumble, and all you hope for is to do well in the life of Uxbal and his children.




Javier Bardem as "Oxbow" with his two children, Anna and Matteo, at Biutiful

Biutiful is a film that shows the other side of Barcelona, that of the underworld, of poverty, of blackness, but it is also a realistic side-by-side: Copywriters in central city squares, the camera follows the African retailers running with their things on the shoulder, produced by Chinese craftsmen who work all day in inhumane heat, an extremely bleak but realistic recording of the lives of all those who are "illegal immigrants" a better living conditions for another life that seems elusive.




Immigrants working underground in Barcelona

The director of the film and "meter" of the most magical filmic realism, Alejandro Inarritos, makes the audience listen to the protagonist's pain and longing for life, which, unfortunately, is frustrated by many kinds of difficulties.
And in a nutshell, the end titles are falling and you are trying to realize what you saw in the most painless way for your psyche.
2. Submarino - 2010



If there is one single word that characterizes Submarino, it is the word "cruelty". And it's no wonder if you think it's yet another Scandinavian tragedy signed by Danish director and co-creator of Dogma 95, Thomas Wittenberg, to remind you that just like the characters in the movie, so do all the people in real life. at some point they get to the bottom.




Jakob Cedergren as Nick in Submarino

The story follows the life of Nick (Jakob Cedergren) and his younger brother, who, while not yet finishing elementary school, are already hardened by poverty, hardship and alcohol. Although the two brothers find hope in the face of their newborn brother, replacing their indifferent and alcoholic mother in his care, this little "plank" will not ultimately be their salvation, but trauma will haunt them until adulthood.




The three brothers of Submarino

Nick is now 30 years old and lives in a dark house in a state of total loneliness and destitution, unable to control his anger, which is increasingly exacerbated by his inability to approach his brother. Nick's inability to connect with anyone is reflected in every relationship he seeks: In his superficial relationship with Sophie (Patricia Schumann), her neighbor, whose only hope is to regain her son's custody , but much more in his refusal to accept the mental illness of Ivan, his ex-girlfriend's brother, and the only person with whom he has an elementary communication.




Jakob Cedergren as "Nick" and Morten Rose as "Ivan" in Submarino

For Nick's brother, on the other hand, nothing matters more than his six-year-old son, Martin, with whom he is in a toxic dependency relationship, which prevents him from being a responsible parent.




Peter Plaugborg as Nick's brother in Submarino

The dark side of life and the whole film environment can be incredibly depressing, but you get a weird charm that can't be touched by anything. And I say it doesn't, because we all live in societies and as integral parts of it, we know well that in societies survival comes first. Always.
Two paralyzed beings with a common denominator of parental negligence, the common, guilty trauma that will haunt them, unite them and keep them always at a depressing distance.
3. Virgin Mountain - 2015



Virgin Mountain is an Icelandic film directed by Dagur Curry, screened at the 2015 Berlin Film Festival and rolling in harmony, as is its title track.
The film follows the monotonous life of 40-year-old Fucci (Gran Jonson), an adult but apparently imprisoned in the heart of a young child who still lives with his mother, works in airport luggage and is a virgin rather than a virgin. it is never explicitly stated, it is more implied and let everyone conclude as they think.




Gunn Johnson as "Fuji" on the poster of the movie Virgin Mountain

Fushi has no girlfriend, but she has a friend who shares the same glue about World War II battles with whom they play military games in miniature vehicles. At some point, then, he accidentally drops a coupon for a free dance lesson in school and, after eating a mini swell from his mother, finally goes with a thousand bucks to the free lesson, where he meets taramtaram ... Shofin, a woman with her own peculiarities and her own trauma. Through this acquaintance, the protagonist will discover things about Siofin, but mainly about himself.




Gunnar JÃ³nsson as Fuji and Ilmur KristjÃ¡nsdÃ³ttir as Siofin on Virgin Mountain

Now, she will fall in love with him, he will not fall in love with her, you see and judge her.
Although low budget, Virgin Mountain is one of those films that you say are "unique" cinemas because they invest in their central characters and, by highlighting the smallest details, make them look simple and at the same time complex.
We strongly recommend "Virgin Mountain", because - among other readings that can be made for the film - it poses a basic universal human question: Can love save a person from monotony, social and emotional isolation? And finally, even if man is not born through love, was the experience still worthwhile?
4. Case of Consciousness (No Date, No Signature) - 2018



"Case of Conscience" is an intrusive social and psychological drama by Iranian director Vahid Jalilvand that was expected to shock the eyes of the modern western viewer.
In class warfare in Iran, the tragic death of a little boy comes and sits like a "dumb" in the consciences of the two protagonists, a reputable forensic doctor fromone and the mournful father of the little one on the other.
The case is based on a traffic accident involving a medical examiner and slightly injured an eight-year-old boy. The medical examiner, played by veteran actor Amir Aghaee, avoids calling the police because his security has expired and thus gives some money to the child's father as compensation.




Amir Aghaee as a "medical examiner" & Navid Mohammadzadeh as a "father of the baby" in No Date, No Signature

Although the baby only has bruises after jerking, the coroner offers to take him to the hospital, but the father refuses. The next morning, the coroner will find the boy's corpse in the morgue, with the first report finding death by poisoning.
And then there begins a personal journey of discovery of responsibility for the two tragic persons, the medical examiner on the one hand and the father of the young on the other.

What eventually killed the child?

From the deplorable poverty that led the father to unknowingly feed the dead animal, doing only for the dogs, or from a lack of investigation into the car accident caused by the family and the guilt-ridden forensic doctor?




Navid Mohammadzadeh as "Moosa", father of the youngster in No Date, No Signature

Two simultaneous cases of heavy moral guilt that approach the concepts of "human" and "tragic" by the method of the most raw and naked realism.
5. The Boy in the Striped Pajamas - The Boy Behind the Wire) - 2008



The Boy Behind the Wire is probably the best movie about the Holocaust, because it is only through the eyes of a young child that you can understand the tragic paranoia of mankind.
In this special version of the Holocaust, based on the Irish book by John Boyne, our film introduces us to two young children, separated by a fence: Shmuel (Jack Scanlon) is a Jewish man inside a concentration camp and Bruno (Asa Butterfield) is the youngest son of the camp commander.




"Bruno" (Asa Butterfield) is the son of the camp commander, and behind the fence is the little Jewish "Shmuel" (Jack Scanlon)

Children get to know and become friends straight away, and the few moments they spend together are enough to escape the horror that surrounds them. When Shmuel's father suddenly disappears, the commander's young son, Bruno, enters the camp to help his friend in the search, so soon both the young protagonists are driven to the gas chamber ...
A very powerful film that obviously invokes emotion, but highlights, in the most moving and most adverse of circumstances, the power of true friendship and the boundaries of innocence, capturing your thinking for years.



6. On Body And Soul - 2017



The Soul and the Body is a Hungarian film masterpiece by IldikÃ³ Enyedi, which was justly awarded a Golden Bear and a critics award at the Berlin Festival and what to say firstâ€¦
The film deals with a not-so-ordinary but overly realistic story, both romantic and unorthodox. The two protagonists, the financial manager and the quality control officer of a beef factory, have a mutual love affair when they find out that they see the same dream every night, in which they both appear in the form of a deer. (Somewhere here to insert a "congratulations" to the film for this ingenious psychoanalytic symbolism).



What makes us feel like this extremely melancholic but depressing film?
Both protagonists each fight with their own "demons" (For one the demon may be in the body, the other in the soul). And although in the deep world of the unconscious, everything is fantastical, everything is allowed and all scenarios are possible and possible, what about real life? In real, conscious everyday life, the relationship and connection between two people is not a toy, like the dream knit.

In the real life of loneliness, trauma and circular routine, things are always different and for this reason, "Soul and body" is simply a manifesto of realism and lyrical elegance.
